title: Refraction and lenses - index and focal length

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Two students have a laser and a rectangular block made of an unknown, transparent material, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. They wish to determine the refractive index <math alttext="n sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> of the block material.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine <math alttext="n sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> by making a linear graph. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

Two students have a laser and a rectangular block made of an unknown, transparent material, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. They wish to determine the refractive index <math alttext="n sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> of the block material.

(a) Describe an experimental procedure to collect data that would allow the students to determine <math alttext="n sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> by making a linear graph. Provide enough detail so that the experiment could be replicated, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) For the data collected in the procedure from part (a), describe how the students could create a linear graph and how that graph could be used to determine <math alttext="n sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>n</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math>.

In a second experiment, the students have a converging lens made of the same material. They wish to experimentally determine the focal length of the lens. The lens is used to form images of a candle on a screen. For each of several experimental trials, the students measure the distance <math alttext="d sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></math> between the candle and the lens. They then adjust the position of the screen until the image of the candle is in focus and measure the distance <math alttext="d sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></math> between the screen and the lens. The measured values of <math alttext="d sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="d sub S" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>d</mi><mtext>S</mtext></msub></math> are shown in the table.

ii. On the grid in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i). Clearly scale and label all axes, including units. On the same grid, draw a straight line that best represents the data.
